content.description: Friction and face climbing up the apron.
content.protection: Bolts and some trad gear. The same three bolt rappel anchors of E2
content.location: A few ft. uphill from E3

content.description: climb up face to gain large groove to your left or west and remain in this groove crux until your able to exit onto semi easier friction. I top roped this climb before someone bolted it. It is sustained but definitely is hardest in the groove as I recall.
content.protection: Bring trad gear and widely spaced bolts as usual. There used to be a rappel station above Bert's climb first pitch belay corner. It was stoppers in the corner. There is a early 1990's three bolt rappel station.
content.location: uphill, a very short distance east of the long tongue of slab below the Beak Buttress. Just right of the blueberry filled groove. Belay on Bert's Climb top of first pitch. Rappel or continue up Bert's.

content.description: The entire climb is sustained face and friction. It starts out 5-7 and gets harder (5-8+) in thirty ft and then to sustained (5-9) 50ft to friction bulges (5-9+). After the bulges easier up to the big boulder on the beak route. It was a top rope climb. It got bolted late 80's. It was a top rope I couldn't get through the crux section. I couldn't get through the mid section without being paranoid in 2002. The bolts were deteriorated. I moved right into a right facing corner (5-9) and climbed it instead, midway on the climb. I got in some decent stoppers (1 got fixed by accident). It's a decent corner. After the corner I moved left, back onto this route and escaped higher up onto the Beak Buttress.
content.protection: Widely spaced bolts approximately 15ft apart. This is typical well protected climbing for Owl's Head. Anywhere other than this cliff it would be rated R. Rappelling at boulder is possible off of trees.
content.location: To the east of the start of the Beak Buttress is a long tongue of rock. Climb up the east side of tongue thirty ft. to sloping ledge with belay bolts to start this climb directly up slightly to the left.

content.description: Friction and face climbing on the apron.
content.protection: bolts and some trad gear. Same rappel bolts as E2.
content.location: A few ft. uphill from Power failure.

content.description: climb the large right facing corner with many trees on it until the trees end and do lay backing corner crack to large platform ledge. There was no where to go back then from there but down.
content.protection: Trad gear and I found a vintage pin while rope soloing it.
content.location: Uphill east from tongue. This is the last prominent feature before the largest boiler plate section of this cliff.

content.description: A large apron with six difficult, mostly bolt protected one pitch routes. The climbing is steep friction on beautiful, smooth granite. Many of the routes have serious runouts down low, bring your A game. One set of modern SS ring anchors serves five of the six routes. The rest of the hardware on the face is old and suspect. White Owl, with its line of rusty, homemade angle iron hangers lets you know you are in the right place.
